body: yes the first time it will give some errors, then you need to correct mxnet_predict-all.cc , and then make again.
Do you have any idea about how to reduce the size of jni_libmxnet_predict.so file?
No, sorry. Maybe @antinucleon  can help?

Finally got it to work with USE_CUDA = 1

The configuration did have alot of warnings but I had these flags still set to 0

```

# whether use CUDNN R3 library
USE_CUDNN = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation
# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use
# imbin iteraor
USE_OPENCV = 0

# use openmp for parallelization
USE_OPENMP = 0
```

In the end I setup my osx.mk  following this as a guide https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/843

The file name for OpenBLAS library is libopenblas.dll.a, which can not be recognized by CMake correctly. I am creating a pull request to handle this correctly. Before the PR is merged, you can manually point OPENBLAS_LIB to the libopenblas.dll.a file.

@woodthom2 Can you see below the error file and mxnet_predict-all.cc file

```
c++filt -n _ZN5mxnet2op16SimpleOpRegistry3GetEv
mxnet::op::SimpleOpRegistry::Get()
```

When I do ctrl+F with `SimpleOpRegistry` in your file and my file I can see similar item. So whats missing?
[error.txt.zip](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/291173/error.txt.zip)
[mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/291174/mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip)

Finally I am successful.
#include "src/operator/operator_util.cc" was missing from mxnet_predict0.cc. That solve the issue but my so file size is more than 6.7 MB . Last time when I was able to make a successful SO file, size was 6.2 MB. I wonder why?
@MonkeyTang Thanks! This was indeed a bug!

@MonkeyTang OK, then it is an easy case: you can just force rebind the module. And thanks for fixing the bug. Since it seems that you are now able to get it working properly, I am closing this issue. Please feel free to reopen this if needed. Thanks again!

hi yizhi,

thanks for the feedbacks. we have several options for the fault tolerance.
we tried the most expensive solution before, namely continuous chain
replication described in the osdi paper. it, however, may affect the
performance a lot, and hard to make it run smoothly.

the current ps-lite has little fault tolerance. the reason is that i want
to understand more about the environment. so my questions are:
1. is it possible to set the highest job priority. so that the chance to be
   preempted within several iteration is little. then we can checkpoint the
   model for every iteration.
2. is it possible to make the servers stable even the worker may be
   preempted at any time. then we can do continuous fault tolerance for
   workers.

we are also considering to run mxnet as a service in cloud such as aws. we
hope to have a single solution works on both situations.

Hi Mu,

I think your idea make sense. We do have chance to checkpoint in most use-cases. For the 2nd point, the only way can cause server crash I see is the physical node itself goes out. In such situation, which is rare, we can simply fail the application. But as you said, we do need continuous fault tolerance for
workers.
Fine. I'll revise the implementation tomorrow.

Thanks, I will test that tonight when I get hold of my pc. However, if the problem is due to async loop, why does it take unlimited memory? E.g., for a longer loop this script will run out of memory, like the one in my training case. Also I still need the async loop for the benefit of parallelization.
On CPU, OpenBLAS usually will occupy all CPU cores. In MXNet, engine will occupy one or two cores, and OpenBLAS will take all remained.

I am just asking about the possibility of a custom layer, which selects, say 75 of these 100 images according to an inner operation and propagate a (75,3,200,200) shaped batch into the next layer. I do not know "75" in advance, it will determined by the layer itself.
Sorry for previous short reply, I mean you can do re-binding similar to variable input shape.

How do I do that? Following my previous example, in every iteration, I give a minibatch of size (100,3,200,200), I copy that into the input array, bind it, get the executor, but in the symbolic network, I have my custom operation, which gets (100,3,200,200) as an input and gives (N,3,200,200) as output, where 1 <= N <= 100. N depends on the current minibatch and not known until the forward pass is called. Is this possible to do?
You may refer the example in RCNN, it is very similar: Input shape is different https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/rcnn/solver.py#L78

I cannot run the example currently, but I wonder how the input shape is different? What type of data does it process? Does the batch shape change from iteration to iteration?
Yes. Each batch's input shape is difference. You can either reshape exectuor, or re-bind

But the number of samples (the first dimension) does change DURING the forward-backward passes, right? So, if the minibatch contains 100 samples, not all the 100 samples are fully processed in that iteration?

Sorry I missed it at beginning. You can cut your execution graph into two executor: before F and after F. After F, you can use re-bind or reshape. Sample code:

```
sym1 = xxx
sym1 = F(sym1)
sym2 = yyy

exe1 = sym1.bind(...)
exe2 = sym2.bind(...) # need grad for data

for batch in diter:
   exe1.forward(...)
   outputs = exe.outputs
   exe2 = exe2.reshape() # determined by output shape
   exe2.forward()
   exe2.backward()
   # make back prop grad shape, pad exe2.grad_dict["data"] to correct shape
   exe1.backward([grad])
   #sgd
```

@Gazillionth Thanks for helping confirm that. @mli @tqchen @antinucleon @piiswrong, can you please help take a look? If the issue indeed exists, it could badly affect the data alignment when `CSVIter` is to be merged with other iterators. Thank you.

Thanks for the answer. In my case, if the network is deep, I can have 2,3, sometimes 4 Fs. I believe this approach would result in a big performance hit then, due to the partial executions and memory copy overheads in between the executions, right?
No, there won't be big performance hit. All op are async, it will be scheduled automatically instead of running in a simple queue
Has there been any movement on this? I'd be interested to see the correct way to handle this!

Check: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-model-gallery
And: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/tools/caffe_converter

Ok, but in order to exe2,exe3, etc to start, exe1 should first execute and prepare its results, so all other executors will be blocked. What will be the benefit of async execution here? All function calls to the MxNet library and initializations will be done in parallel, so the overheads will be hidden, I suppose?

While running exe2, if it is not blocked manually, exe1 is able to run on next batch. This is a difference between MXNet and other toolkit. A potential problem for reshape exe in middle is out of memory. So some manual wait_to_read call is necessary. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2264
There is a work_load_list param that does this

I read the issue 2264, it seems the general problem of async execution, since the memory gets being copied continually into the buffers as the forward execution is blocked. I assume this problem appears when the network is too deep and the execution takes too long, so a lot of memory gets allocated while waiting.

I'm not an R person, but here is a python example showing a 30-valued output multiple regression setup on some artificial data. This model converges:

``` python

import find_mxnet
import mxnet as mx
from load_data import load
from sklearn.cross_validation import train_test_split
import logging
import pdb as pdb
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def get_mlp():
    """
    multi-layer perceptron
    """

    outLabl = mx.sym.Variable('softmax_label')

    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')

    flat = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=data)

    fc1  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = flat, name='fc1', num_hidden=100)
    act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
    fc2  = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act1, name='fc2', num_hidden=30)
    net  = mx.sym.LinearRegressionOutput(data=fc2, label=outLabl, name='linreg1')

    return net

#
# Load data
#
# Create artificial data
X = np.ones((2140, 9216)).reshape((2140, 1, 96, 96))
y = 0.6*np.ones((2140, 30))

#
# Setup iterators
#
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.33, random_state = 42)
trainIter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data = X_train, label = y_train, batch_size = 64)
valIter   = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data = X_test , label = y_test , batch_size = 64)

#
# Multidevice kvstore setup and logging
#
kv = mx.kvstore.create('local')
head = '%(asctime)-15s Node[' + str(kv.rank) + '] %(message)s'
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG, format=head)

#
# Get model and train
#
net = get_mlp()

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx                = mx.gpu(),
        symbol             = net,
        num_epoch          = 15,
        learning_rate      = 0.001,
        momentum           = 0.9,
        wd                 = 0.00001,
        initializer        = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34),
        )
model.fit(X=trainIter, eval_data=valIter, batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(1,50), epoch_end_callback=None, eval_metric='rmse')

#
# Prediction
#

valIter.reset()
for prediction in model.predict(valIter):
    print prediction
    pdb.set_trace()

```

usually the speedup you observe was not really speedup, but the asynchronous executions that are pushed but not finished get counted as finished. It is usually fine to use the default evaluation metric provided.

usually the speedup you observe was not really speedup, but the asynchronous executions that are pushed but not finished get counted as finished. It is usually fine to use the default evaluation metric provided.

for a parameter, e.g. the weight for a layer, if its size is less than MXNET_KVSTORE_BIGARRAY_BOUND, we randomly assign it to a node. otherwise, we evenly divided it to multiple nodes.

@Darwin-Lu you can use multimachines with the cost of increasing the batch size, it works fine up to some point. namely, when the batch size is large than a particular number, it slows down the convergence. one reason is that if there are a lot of similar examples in a single batch, then we waste our computations. 

some heuristics: 
- if you training takes >1 days on a single machine, which means you have a big problem, then it's worth to try multiple machines. 
- if your training data has over k classes, then it often ok to have batch size > k.

To add an extra data point, that I think is very relevant:

I have a smaller version of the same model that works. Here's a line from the model:

```
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in2, in3, in4, num_args=4)
```

If I change this code to:

```
outputs.append(mx.sym.BlockGrad(in3))
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in2, in3, in4, num_args=4)
```

It starts hitting the same issue as above on the `Concat` op. Note that even though I block the grad, the input to the Concat is NOT the output of BlockGrad. So seems like blocking grads on that particular argument starts breaking stuff. Note that if I change it to (reorder in2 and in3):

```
outputs.append(mx.sym.BlockGrad(in3))
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in3, in2, in4, num_args=4)
```

it still fails, and still with `ord=2`, even though the `in3` is now the second argument (with ordinal=1), so it makes me suspect that ordinal has nothing to do with the order of inputs to the `Concat`.

Finally, if I change it to:

```
outputs.append(mx.sym.BlockGrad(in2))
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in3, in2, in4, num_args=4)
```

Then it does not fail. So it is specific to `in3`. If I block any of `in1`, `in2` and `in4`, it works, but if I block `in3` it breaks. The difference in them that `in1`, `in2` and `in4` come from Embedding and FullyConnected layers, while `in3` comes from a pointwise multiplication of some activations over `SliceChannel` output.
@tqchen Any ideas?

The last time this happens. I recall it was due to some output of slice
channel not binded for gradient and in gradient construction, the supposed
to be initialized slice channel output gradient was not initialized(
because it did not get binded)

I confirmed that I have no dangling outputs.

Most interesting thing is that if I replace

```
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in2, in3, in4, num_args=4)
```

with

```
flow = mx.sym.Concat(in1, in2, num_args=2)
flow = mx.sym.Concat(flow, in3, num_args=2)
flow = mx.sym.Concat(flow, in4, num_args=2)
```

Then the issue doesn't repro anymore.

I have another issue that might be relevant or not. When I switch to multiple Concats  to get around the `kNotInitialized` error, I hit another issue:

```
  what():  [15:03:37] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:306: [15:03:37] src/operator/./embedding-inl.h:85: Check failed: (req[embedding::kData]) == (kNullOp) Embedding layer doesn't support calculate data gradient 1
```

An extra `1` at the end is my debug output -- it's the actual `type` (and stands for `kWriteTo`). All my `Embedding` layers only accept `mx.sym.Variable` as inputs, so none of their inputs should be `kWriteTo`. However, some of my `Embedding` layers share their inputs. If I duplicate shared inputs (so that each `Variable` is fed to at most one `Embedding`), the issue goes away.

With both hacks in place my models runs, but the fact that the hacks work suggests that both issues are real bugs, and not just a result of me forgetting some dangling outputs.
